["Is CO2 the earth's Thermostat?  

Carbon dioxide has nothing to do with causing global warming. CO2 Is currently trace at 400 ppm. That is one carbon-dioxide molecule for every 2500 parts of the atmosphere. Humans contribute only a scant 16 ppm which is 4% of the total CO2 accumulated in a year. CO2 only holds heat for a few seconds and there is not enough to drive climate- it is thermodynamically impossible!  Also, bear in mind, that Water Vapor is the earth's most abundant and effective Greenhouse Gas.  CO2 is only 5% of the earth's GHG; Water Vapor is 95% of the earth's GHG and holds heat far longer than CO2.    Lastly, CO2 will increase only after temperatures rise (eg. El Nino) and oceans degas.  Conversely, CO2 levels drop as temperatures cool. In other words, CO2 levels are influenced by heat or the lack thereof and therefore do not drive climate but follow climate.  Clearly, CO2 is actually a thermometer and Not a Thermostat.", 'This was good to mention the global warming benefits northern countries, we count too. Also if we eliminate global warming we will introduce another iced age. How much fun does that sound. ?', 'Katherine, despite your many great talks, I have to disagree with you (and probably most others) regarding CO2 being a pollutant.  Atmospheric pollutants are "substances that accumulate in the air to a degree that is directly harmful to living organisms or to materials exposed to the air".  CO2, at 420 ppm at present, does not 'directly' harm living organisms exposed to the air. Rather, it helps warm the planet, and its the heat energy that is impacting negatively on living organisms.  CO2 is, after all, essential for all life on Earth.  We would not have O2 were it not for CO2 and the photosynthesis process. Plants came before all animals and insects, because it was CO2 that eventually provided enough O2 for animals to evolve.  CO2, prior to humans producing far too much through fossil fuels, helped keep Earth's climate in balance, around 15 degs. C.  Without GHGs, Earth's mean global temperature would hover around -20 degs. C, and life as we know it could not exist. 

Furthermore, water vapour, yes H2O, makes up about 50% of all GHGs. If global temperatures increased by 2 degs C, say from 15 to 17C, then H2O vapour would increased by almost 25%, which might be enough to put the climate over the top.  Therefore, if CO2 is a pollutant, then you must also include H2O vapour as a pollutant.  Where wpuld that leave you?  You should not lump CO2, H2O, and N2O in the same category of pollutants as CO,  SO2, and NO2.  I cannot fathom labelling something essential to all life as a pollutant! The court verdict in favour of Mass. over EPC was therefore wrong, and i suspect EPC had more scientific expertise than either Mass. or the court.  So there!', 'humans and animals are carbon based life forms so how can it be bad?', 'So if it causes global warming, why did Texas just have winter?', 'First, CO2 is NOT the apocalyptic catastrophe all these leftist imbeciles think it is. CO2 is necessary for life to exist on Earth. 

Second, if we want to capture carbon, it would be A LOT CHEAPER to simply enact a National Tree Planting Program with proper forest management.', 'This is a load of bullshit.', 'Trees and plants are starving for CO2. We do not have too much. Stop peddling fear over another globalist manifested crisis. Talk about the military weather warfare modification programs and the adverse effects of altering earth‚Äôs natural frequencies.  Research the advancements and patents on controlling the weather. The wild fires are due to poor forest management and the increase in diseases and viral infections are due to toxic spraying that kills off good bacteria needed to maintain a healthy natural immune system. What are the adverse effects of 5G and higher frequencies?', 'Do we have too much of it for plants? Because the world is greening and plants have better yields with more Co2. They would be healthiest at about 1200-1500 ppm debatably.', 'This is ridiculous. CO2 is a life provider and has almost no ill effects. Also, the idea that we know how CO2 is absorbed and shared by the atmosphere is absurd.']

['What are the papers you‚Äôre citing? Strange that you wouldn‚Äôt have included them so people can verify for themselves', "except it's not simple is it?", "Bjorn Lomborg-- The Cost of Climate Alarmism
Climate models - are they ALWAYS WRONG?
Can Climate Models Predict Climate Change?
Making The Energy Crisis Worse
Climate Models that Predicted Warming are Wrong
all observed data indicate the models are wrong and they indicate this consistently! So, it's pointless to have a discussion about what the models predict when we already know the models are not a reliable representation of reality.", 'Something very interesting happens to the Earth's Climate roughly every 100,000 years.  The Earth's temperature very quickly spikes up 8 to 15 degrees Celcius, followed by at least 10,000 years of relatively stable warm temperatures.  This is then followed by a rapid decline in temperature leading to 80,000 to 90,000 years of glaciation where half of North America is covered by glaciers, during which time the Earth slowly gets colder.  Then the cycle repeats.  The last time we experienced rapid warming was about 11,000 years ago.  All of human civilization arose during this brief warm period, thanks in part to the fertile crescent in the Middle East making grains more available.

We should be in the cool-down phase by now, but anthropogenic greenhouse gases have at least temporarily delayed it.  It was predicted in the 1970s that we were entering a new ice age.  A period from 1500 to 1850 has been labeled "the little ice age", however, atmospheric CO2 levels started to go up in the 1800s.  Some have said that no matter what we do we can't avoid the next period of mass glaciation roughly 10,00 years from now, while others have suggested that we can delay it.  Previous ice ages have caused massive declines in the human population.

These temperature cycles are caused by the roughly 5 different Malankovich cycles aligning with each other to produce rapid warming.  These cycles affect the Earth's orbit and its axial tilt.  The Earth is currently halfway between its maximum tilt and its minimum tilt, which has a 41,000-year cycle.  At the maximum tilt, the glaciers melt more, reducing the Earth's albedo, which means that less sunlight is reflected into space.  The increasing temperatures cause the oceans to release more of their stored CO2 into the atmosphere, which creates a temporary positive feedback loop.  The warming effect of CO2 in the atmosphere is logarithmic, which means that it reaches a saturation point, producing a temporarily stable warm climate.

I don't understand why the cycle is every 100,000 years instead of every 41,000 years, and the Wikipedia article talks about this being an "issue" that they don't understand.  Prior to about 3 million years ago, the cycle was every 41,000 years.  However, we have technically been in an ice age for the last 2.5 million years.

The periods of mass glaciation helped drive human evolution.  Climate Change tended to push physical changes in humans and our ape-like ancestors.', 'The problem is your missing other key elements that could or do affect the climate.  This is why the models fail, you don‚Äôt have the data to properly predict the future climate, a lot of the data doesn‚Äôt exist.  Thats ok but lets stop pretending we know things we can‚Äôt.  That‚Äôs very unscientific.', "Clouds, possibly one of the biggest variables in the climate system but not included in any meaningful way in climate models. You can't predict weather beyond a few days with any accuracy so how on earth can climate be predicted years in advance?

The one true thing the IPCC said is the earth's climate is a chaotic system and can't be predicted. Climate models are no more than parlour games for pseudoscientists and certainly should not be used for global policy.", 'Thanks üòä', "Seriously? William Happer and Freeman Dyson's 1982 climate model way overpredicted climate sensitivity. Turns out they were in the middle of the pack on estimation. The current models are well documented to way over estimate climate sensitivity, with the Russian model being the closest. Maybe in 50 years we might be close enough with models to make policy, but in the mean time we will have climate hysteria.", 'Love your work Katharine üíú. Keep rockin!', "I'm guessing core samples and dating help identify times when climate was similar to know but how does an know how much ice was left ?"]

If you think government is your friend - you don't know history.", 'weather is a chaotic evil system confirmed', 'A MAJOR PROBLEM!!!!

The amount of statistical data used in averaging long term CLIMATE  is very, very, small as compared to the large amount of the data used in predicting short term WEATHER. Let me explain, 

Lets say, for example, I have a massive bag of marbles which contains blue, green, and red marbles, and lets say over the last 1000 days I have randomly pulled out of the bag an even amount of colored marbles, Can I CONFIDENTLY say based on the past 1000 days that I will once again pull out an even amount of colored marbles over the next 1000 days?? Yes!  Because the sample size of 1000 is very large. But lets now change this scenario, what if I only pulled out marbles over a period of 100 days, could I with confidence say that I will pull out an even amount of colored marbles in the next 100 days? Lets now apply this to WEATHER AND CLIMATE.

It is true that WEATHER is what happens to the atmosphere in a certain place in a certain time" (short term) but the AMOUNT OF STATISTICAL DATA used in the forecast models is based on many years and thousands of days of observable patterns. Furthermore, the modelling is refined by technological advancements and satellite imagery. Therefore, meteorologists, on average are about 80% accurate in their short term predictions.

In distinction CLIMATE is what happens to weather conditions in an area over a long period of time,  But how many years of climate data are the forecast models based upon? Is this amount of data large enough to make accurate forecasts??????

Even if we use climate data going back 100+ years, we only have a sample size of 100 or so on which we are forecasting into the future, and unlike weather forecasting which is modified on the basis of day to day weather patterns, there are no observable CLIMATE patterns which the CLIMATE forecast models can use to make refinements as CLIMATE is long term. If we wanted to have a much greater degree of confidence in our predictions, we would have to wait say another 100 years (arguably longer) and then look back over the previous 100 to refine our predictions. 

This, I believe, is a MAJOR UNDERLYING WEAKNESS OF CLIMATE FORECASTING. Put simply, there is not enough data to make predictions with a high degree of certainty.', "The angle of rotation of the Earth has changed by 15 degrees 8 million years ago. ['What with that ice shelf the size of Delaware having just broken off from part of West Antarctica, and experts agreeing with del Conto and the other guy that we have a distinct possibility of 11 feet of sea level rise by 2100, I‚Äôd say we need to put the pedal to the metal as far as direct removal of CO2 from the air goes. Also, I really think this could provide us with protection against a disaster so bad that global warming and nuclear war might seem minor in comparison, i.e., a major volcanic eruption, the size of the Krakatoa eruption of more than a 100 years ago or much bigger. As I understand it, the tectonic plate system that includes Yellowstone has been rebounding with the huge amount of melting of glaciers over it. Also, fracking is going on around Yellowstone, with resulting frequent earthquakes. A large eruption of Yellowstone can‚Äôt be ruled out within our lifetimes. And as bad as the ash, pyroclastic flow, and fire would be, it seems that the real killer is the huge release of sulfates into the stratosphere, where they could cause a decade or so of up to several degrees Celsius of cooling. We have to remember that this means many more killing frosts in particular, and that this could even be an extinction event comparable to the eruption of the Mount Toba volcan 75,000 years ago, which is \n widely believed to have killed off most of humanity, as well as other plants and animals. It seems likely to me that this could be easily offset just by having CO2 reversibly sequestered in the many underground caverns on the planet, including those created by the fossil fuel companies in the course of removing vast amounts of oil. Even a medium sized volcanic eruption would be an unparalleled disaster in terms of crop loss due to a volcanic winter.', 'Hi Dr Hayhoe, I was talking the other day with a person that believes that Global Warming is just a scam, and his argument was very valid to me ears. "The rest of Knutson‚Äôs findings, however, are considerably more worrisome. As he explains, in the warmer Atlantic of the future, more persistent wind shear will likely ‚Äúweed out some storms, but not all.‚Äù And the models indicate that the storms that do materialize and grow will probably be more intense. Knutson‚Äôs latest modeling study projects that the number of category-4 and category-5 hurricanes in the Atlantic will double by the end of this century, making a catastrophic storm like Katrina considerably more likely.

Knutson notes several other worrisome trends for the hurricanes of the future as well. He warns that today‚Äôs climate models uniformly project that the hotter atmosphere brought about by global warming will retain more moisture. For developing hurricanes, this means more intense precipitation‚Äîsome 20 percent higher rainfall rates, according to Knutson‚Äôs calculations. In addition, he says, current estimates of rising sea levels over the coming century mean that the storm surges caused by intense hurricanes are likely to be more devastating than ever before."

['None of those positive stories you list are enough to prevent 2C.', 'Your doing great work. Keep it up. My wife and I purchased an old house in Concord, MA in 2008. I had left my job to raise our twin boys, then two years old. We build a home that received a LEED Platinum certification not because money was easy, we simply invested in what gave us long term value. We spent less on building the home and land then my neighbors paid to buy a standard home made by local builds. We spend about 90% less to operate our home than they do. Also we purchased electric cars to replace your gas powered minivan and sedan when they reach 10 years old. Our person carbon footprint is now very low and still improving. Later as the kids started school and needed me less I started volunteering with my town. Working with the town, so much solar has been installed our town utility is experiencing low load issues, plugin vehicles are everywhere, air and ground source heat pump are in a lot of newly weatherized home, Concord was the first town to ban small single use plastic water bottles, our utility is now 100% non-carbon emitting, Concord received the first fully electric school bus in the US, Concord set emissions reduction targets and fund them, and our utility has a strategic plan to modernize to meet the growing need for energy management services like load control, V2G, energy storage and energy efficiency programs. A lot is happening but more is still to be done.', 'What I am trying to do is to explain that there is possible to fix global warming in as little as 10 years by using leaves sequestering method 
http://www.grisanik.com/blog/carbon-sequestration-by-leaves-and-dead-plants-carbonisation/

But I need to connect with more people with deep knowledge who are able to validate the method.', 'My Climate Reality Project training was in Denver in March 2017.  My good news story is about my second presentation which occurred in early May.  About a month ago, someone recognized me from my May presentation. ['What part of a hurricane takes in energy from the sea surface, only the eye, only the outer rim, the entire circular cloud cover?', 'Which "climate change" are you talking about? The fake, Biggest Oil Rockefeller globalist kidnapping of the term -- recent, man made and dangerous? Or the original, scientific term -- ancient, natural and mostly benign?

Dr. Hubert Lamb's work (CRU E. Anglia) showed that the Little Ice Age produced far more violent storms than we've had in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Warming reduces the thermal gradient, resulting in less energy for storms overall. Cooling produces greater danger from storms because polar cold is forced closer to equatorial heat.

We live in an Ice Age! Storms are normal during an Ice Age because of the thermal gradients. Melt all that ice, and you short-circuit the battery that energizes the storms.

And our Modern Warm Period is the coldest of the Holocene's 10 major warm periods. Heck, the Vikings could grow crops in Greenland for hundreds of years. So far, this warm period, it's been too cold to do that. And the Medieval Warm Period was a global phenomenon.

The far warmer Holocene Optimum resulted in a green Sahara for 3,000 years. Too many lies about warming. Life thrives in the warmth and dies in the ice. Agriculture was impossible before the Holocene -- for 90,000 years -- because cold oceans don't evaporate enough to give plentiful rain.', "Dr. Hayhoe, I know you probably don't read Youtube comments, but you do a great job. I always tell people you are my favorite climatologist. Thank you.", "That's 80 degrees Fahrenheit, but yes, everything else is true.", 'God bless Katharine Hayhoe.
eddie evans - ClimateDeception.Net']

Johnson‚Äôs White House released ‚ÄúRestoring the Quality of our Environment‚Äù,\xa0a report that described the impacts of climate change, and foretold dramatic Antarctic ice sheet loss, sea level rise, and ocean acidification.\xa0 That 1965 White House report stated: ‚ÄúCarbon dioxide is being added to the earth‚Äôs atmosphere by the burning of coal, oil, and natural gas at the rate of 6 billion tons a year. By the year 2000 there will be about 25 percent more CO2 in our atmosphere than present.‚Äù\nCatastrophically, on the 50th anniversary of the White House report, CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere are indeed at 399 ppm: 25 percent over 1965 levels, exactly as predicted 50 years ago.' \n'Science.http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/energy-environment/259342-fifty-years-ago-the-white-house-knew-all-about-climate", 'In addition to the Industrial Revolution\'s obvious increase of carbon in the atmosphere causing the "screeching halt" of the next ice age, it should be noted that humans have already been exerting their impact on the climate in a gentler, even beneficial way.  The Milankovich cycles suggest that there should have been an 8000 year decline, were it not for the human introduction of agriculture.  William Ruddiman, paleoclimatologist and Professor Emeritus at the University of Virginia suggests that the unprecedented leveling of our CO2 levels and climate have been the result of humans gradually removing carbon sinks from the planet -- our forests, in the name of agriculture.  Since most mass extinction of species happen when there are drastic changes in climate, we have unwittingly been performing a service to biodiversity by being controllers of a biological thermostat.  Of course, that was less than one billion people, and there arises biodiversity issues with loss of forest habitats. Although the Industrial Revolution added 0.6 degrees to the world climate, Ruddiman points out that agriculture has gradually created a differential of 0.8 degrees from where the Milankovich cycles suggested we\'d be!  That means two things -- first, we can stop beating ourselves up over being apart from nature -- nature (with God at the helm, if you will) has enlisted us as keepers of the biothermostat!  Second, we have an incredibly powerful tool in modulating both agriculture and deforestation/reforestation, and mitigating fossil fuels isn\'t the only tool in humanity\'s global cooling kit.  Our choice of food is the key factor in this modulation -- with the crisis created by industrialization (primarily by the energy sector but also by agriculture).  If agriculture could be responsible for adding 0.8 degrees to cancel the ice age, we can also cancel a significant portion of the climate crisis by eliminating animals from our diet.  How fast can we do it?  It\'s something that I\'ve already done and it\'s something that you can do today.  The fight to keep oil in the ground must continue -- in fact, we may need to have some fossil fuels left in our thermostat tool kit several hundred years from now when the Milankovich cycles start to push that ice age even harder.  Whenever anyone talks about geoengineering most methods are treacherous and uncertain.  Technology has given us the means to measure our planet\'s fever (hear that Mr. Trump?  We still need NASA) and use an all-natural remedy -- reforestation and elimination of food animals.  http://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v292/n3/box/scientificamerican0305-46_BX4.html', 'Education about the subject of global warming/climate change is one of the greatest challenges of our day. And it is a necessary precursor to action. All styles, all targeted audiences, all types of messengers are needed. A majority of people will soon have to do their part. Thank you for doing yours cheerfully. The world needs you just as you are.']

First, the title suggests there's going to be some explanation of why overpopulation's a myth. But then we get an _ad hominem_ attack on Malthus, with no attempt at myth-busting.

Second, and more serious, the video totally misrepresents what Malthus wrote, by quoting bits out of context.

Google "Irony in Thomas Malthus' Essay on Population", for example. You'll find stuff like this:

"Thomas Malthus had some harsh views on population growth and the poor, but one must not mistake ironic, sarcastic, or satiric passages for his own beliefs. For example, the first paragraph of Book IV, Chapter V, of the 1826 edition of "An Essay on the Principle of Population" is sometimes quoted to show that Malthus wished genuine harm to the poor. ['Where do you normally get your clothes?
Also if you want to support this channel, you can do so on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/OurChangingClimate', 'Socialist Propaganda disguised as sustainability essay. You are pathetic.', 'i don't believe that a majority of people's sense of self expression is really tied to fashion... maybe a small percentage. most just mindlessly spend money. it's not "being addicted to fashion as self expression" when you buy and wear the same basic items (jeans, t shirt) over and over... it's just a habit of spending money they develop when they're young and keep forever, has nothing to do with style.', 'In past people were living in tribes and each tribe had a representable patterns and way of making clothes.', 'Easy, we buy higher quality items, wear our clothes longer, love the clothes we buy, get picky about what we buy, purchase second hand clothing And donate to second hand stores or giveaway to friends:).', 'but you dont have to, you cayn produce this all wiht out humans, evne designer cloths', 'In other words we are F'd
  I almost never buy clothes, most of what i have were purchased by other people or used items, i even still wear clothes i had in the 90's lol and some vintage stuff to boot.
  One example i look at is the Aral sea where cancer rates are supposed to be 25x higher than average. Industry polluted the Aral sea but the true culprit was the cotton industry in the "Stans" and The part of Russia just north of the once 4th largest lake in the world. The pesticides, herbicides and other chemicals used have ended up in a huge dust bowl that was not long ago a thriving sea / lake. In March 2020 the dust was settling here in the French Alps for a few weeks, it carried over Italy and Spain also. Who knows the damage it's done across the planet. I don't generally follow dust storms leaving the Aral sea or other dangerous zones with similar residues ready to become airborne. I happened to be part of a small group of people who questioned the dust, a week or so later we found a link to a site or page declaring dangerous PM 10 dust and it showed some hotspots in Europe. Later by chance I happened across a youtube channel (youstorm) that follows weather and had happened to report on the dust and showed it's path via animated satellite images. This happened to coincide with the 1st lockdown. (Another strange fact is there was once a bio lab, similar to the one near Wuhan situated somewhere remote on the once thriving Aral sea). However lets concentrate on the toxic residues from such industries, i happen to think the wave of freak deaths in Wugan was more to do with excess burning of "dirty coal" during a historically high peak demand phase in general. For example we topped out at 90 million cars produced annually in 2019.  Hence WHO stepped in but lets also remember the amount of times WHO has been busted for corruption!
  I could go on for hours. The new industry should be "the local" we repair and modify your clothes shops!', 'When I moved to another country because I was unhappy in the current one, my desire to shop for clothes dropped drastically. I could live a little more instead of just shopping and filling that hole in my heart.', "I buy my most of clothes from a Chicago manufacturer. Socks from Vermont. Eyewear from South Carolina. Shoes from Michigan, but they got bought by a Chinese company, so I'm looking for a new local manufacturer.", 'Being able to identify a problem does not imply ability to solve it. Suggesting socialism as a solution to fast fashion shows both naivety and a lack of history knowledge.
Planned economy has been tried many times and failed catastrophically every single time. That said I would love to see the power shift within individual companies to move away from the feudal way of having few owners to instead have all workers at a company be co-owners, but not necessarily to the same extent.']

["Note: There's some sloppy research and wording in here. I'm sorry. (1) The white paper by Michael Kelly is funded by a climate-denial think tank. (other, better sources linked below) (2) I want to make clear that I don't think EVs are the devil, I just think they are not THE solution to future transportation. It feels as if there's such a heavy emphasis on EVs and comparably little on public transit. I believe it should be the opposite. There will always be a role for EVs, but it must be much smaller than what it is currently. Please read further on this and come to your own conclusions. There are some great counterpoints in the comments! I have a bunch of resources in the description!

On material demands of a clean energy transition: https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/ffd2a83b-8c30-4e9d-980a-52b6d9a86fdc/TheRoleofCriticalMineralsinCleanEnergyTransitions.pdf
On production of EV batteries: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-02222-1", 'Some serious BS in this vid lol', "Gasoline, diesel, electric........the radical/liberal/lying/leftist/prog mob doesn't want us to have ANY cars!!!!!!!!!!!", 'Yes, try something else and increase tax again.', "Notice that many of those that support these initiatives have a common link: city dwellers. The most important thing that is ignored or not brought into view is what makes this challenging: suburbanites.
Remember, in the US, where the suburban landscape was practically born, you have many that left the urban centers for a more relaxed, less crowded life. Where adults could enjoy the hard-earned fruits of their labor, be it physical or mental. That also means the right to move about whenever one chooses, not to be constrained to a bus/train schedule. It lent to the creation of shopping centers, where accessibility to many goods and services were possible. Later on, home delivery/serviceability made living even easier. The 'nuclear family' jargon was identified with suburban living, where families could be able to make their own way, without the prying eyes and ears of others. 

It's not surprising that some have a disdain for such living, usually those that are younger, more socially inclined. It is when one gets older, better employed and more settled that wants to occupy something with more room for a family to grow besides a town home or a semi-detatched house. Even if that person or couple were to be employed in a major or secondary city, personal transportation will still serve these people. Using mass transit to take them to a certain length, then transferring to their own vehicles to go home or to take care of personal duties.

In any attempt at planning you will have to include these residential areas, as these are the most influential in both social and political matters.", 'Mostly misleading propaganda video. Almost certainly sponsored by the billions and billions of fossil fuel profits made from killing the planet.  Dont be naive', 'Public transport in USA will not work. Lets just keep on makeing ICE more efficient - something we are good at doing. Transport only accounts for 30% of CO2 emmisions - and cars are a lot less than that 30%. EVs are evil.', '2:04 I own an electric vehicle because it accelerates quick, drives quiet and have a 18 months service cycle. I charge at home and have not visited a petrol station for the last year and a bit. 

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm better, EV just suits my usage and budget. It has nothing to do with virtue signalling, it‚Äôs just a better car', 'CO2 does not matter. Get a brain. Also we are going into a cooling period now. Stop believing political science.', "I upgraded my electric cabin scooter with much bigger batteries and fast charging. With our electric grid I calculated that I have about 10g co2e/km of lifecycle emissions, but I can have advantages of cars without high cost or environmental impact. Also parking is free because my cabin scooter is considered moped so I can park at sidewalks if there is enough space for pedestrians. Electric public transport is good if you only need to be in city but I need to travel outside city so I using electric bus doesn't make sense because my cabin scooter is much cheaper to operate and I have space for my stuff like groceries. With bus I would have to use my backbag to have my stuff with me and it's just bit annoying. Also I don't like to be around that many people so if bus is quite full I would just stand rather than to sit next to unknown person."]

Every bit of the economy would somehow find a way to benefit off of this situation... I don't get why we haven't even Given it a chance?? If it doesn't help? ['üí° What do you do for the holidays?
üëç Consider commenting and liking the video!!! It really helps this video beat that unruly algorithm!
üîó  If you want to watch a video looking at consumerism definitely check out this one: https://youtu.be/x0ckvo2Z5BU', 'Q: Have you ever disliked all of a company‚Äôs YouTube videos?', "I always wonder why so many American Christians aren't against the comodififcation of such a sacred holiday, goes to show how Capitalism corrupts all", '"especially the white ruling class"... these pointless, racist jabs are not need and why refuse to subscribe.', "Keep going. Don't give up, Never", 'I have always hated frivolous gifts growing up. I hate the makeup kits and bath and body works kits. The generic products slapped together in prettier packaging. I have tried to really make sure that I give intentional gifts, that are going to be maximum value for the recipient, not maximum quantity or cost. I gave my cousins lunch boxes one year for Christmas, because I knew they always packed lunches but never really had a lunch box. I doubled checked with my Aunt to make sure it was something she thought they would use. I didn‚Äôt expect them to be over the moon about them (they are younger, teenagers). I was shocked when they kept thanking me. They still use them three years later. 
There‚Äôs an old Christmas song that is sung by a lady, and she is singing about what she wants for Christmas. The items were a cashmere sweater, a bike, and a puppy, I think. It always makes me feel like the Christmas season has just turned into a hollow consumerism hedonist fest. Cashmere is expensive, but a few companies are making it sustainable and affordable. Bikes reduce the reliance on cars, and provide good exercise. A puppy, well. A puppy is a good way to get back in touch with the real world. 
It just blows my mind the things we put importance on now days. I think Holidays have turned into ‚Äúwhat stuff can I get to escape the world?‚Äù Instead of ‚Äúwhat items can I use to enhance my interactions with the world?‚Äù It just makes me think about stuff.', 'This video is plagiarising yours https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HCeUUS_3ll0', "Truth, kids don't play with their toys anymore anyways nowadays", 'I rarely spend money, and never spend on holidays', 'My family has generally rejected this--though not as much as I have blatantly hated capitalism. We still do gift giving--but MUCH less and we try to 1. Get things that are consumable in some way or things that people actually need and will use and 2. Buying from smaller local businesses and merchants. 

It helps that a lot of us follow minimalist ideals in the sense of really thinking about what we want and if we use it. (Not in the classist or ableist sense, but through the idea of minimalism that is a mindset that helps you organize your items and prioritize what you need and want through organization.)']

All except life around deep sea vents that is.', 'A stand of trees, a forrest, sequesters CO2 and radiant energy contained in the atmosphere, while producing Oxygen, so that we can all breath. Photosynthesis, an endothermic process, is the phenomenon that is\xa0responsible for this gift of Mother Earth, removing both CO2 and radiant energy. More trees will grow, and they will grow bigger, when there is a\xa0greater amount of CO2 in the atmosphere.\xa0 More trees will sequester more radiant energy thereby cooling Mother Earth. CO2 is a good thing.\xa0Think of CO2 as the control rods of a nuclear reactor. Inserting more\xa0CO2 causes less heat in the ‚ÄúMother Earth reactor‚Äù, and we can all breathe Oxygen. So, why the need to disrupt what seems to be a self regulating system ? Is the actual goal to reduce both plant life and\xa0animal life, the children of Mother Earth ? CO2 is only .04% or 4 parts in ten thousand of the atmosphere.\xa0 It has been both much higher\xa0but not much lower in the past. If it is lowered to .02% or lower, all\xa0life would be in jeopardy. The trees have done a great job.\xa0 So‚Ä¶.STOP burning the forests and STOP chopping the trees down to install solar panels and wind turbines. Many in my neighborhood removed trees to install solar panels and now consume more water to water their lawns as a result of the absence of any shade previously provided by the\xa0trees, and operate their air conditioners more to cool their houses.']

You show a specific situation of soul fire farm with seemingly an unrealistic ratio of output through people. With contributions from donors including the Kellogg foundation (that Kellogg) that make it practices financially sustainable.

The American megafarm is not the paragon either of course, and there are not only these two models.
The model that works best, that maintain a good soil quality, with good productivity per person (which metter for social reasons as well) can be found in Europe imho.
The average Italian farm is between 9 and 11hectars (so about 50% of Italian farms are categorized as "small farm") and family owned. This does not make them not industrial, or not using petrol, but that's what makes a 15% extra labor and not a 150% like what the ideal Kellogg's funded, 15$/kg zucchini window dressing you're showing. In fact Italian farming is one with the most mechanization and the highest productivity per area in the world (not in small part thanks to wine, but also if you isolate produce). 

Japan is another example with even smaller farm distribution and higher industrialization.

So while I encourage the utopian visions of a solarpunk future, if you want to continue the great climate reporting you should also dedicate some time of models that actually work and are (at least environmentally) sustainable right now.', 'Is the creator of this video working on a farm? ["üí° What gives you hope for the future?
üëç Consider commenting and liking the video!!! It really helps this video beat the pesky algorithm!
üîó Check out Saint Andrewism's new Solarpunk video here: https://youtu.be/u-JvyfZVkIM", '"Airships will use less fuel, be locally built, and free to use!"
You can't have all three of these things at the same time. 
Someone has to pay for the fuel or the electricity used for each trip. Even if you're using "free" solar electricity, there are still panels to be built, wiring, expensive batteries to build and house, voltage regulators, and more equipment that requires...and the space to house it, none of which are free.
Someone has to pay for the materials and the laborers to build the airship.
Someone has to pay the pilot, who went through a long, expensive process to get certified to safely fly, and is now spending multiple hours of his/her time transporting you and your bored kids across vast distances.
And in the examples you showed, featuring gargantuan multi-level ships with sundecks and lots of chairs, you'll also need to pay for a crew for things like a secondary/backup pilot, cleaning after a flight, and acting as a buffer between pilots and customers with a lot of questions/demands/complaints.

"Free" is a fun word to toss around when daydreaming, but the truth is: it isn't possible. Forcing someone to work for you without paying them is slavery.

So just buy and spread grass seed when necessary to bolster up the side you're rooting for and then let em fight it out. Grass seed will be cheaper than those chemical fertilizers. You can also use lime and manure, but use it wisely so as not to burn your lawn.", 'Don\'t put me in your bucket of lawn crazies!!! I moved from a rental, 2/1/0, zero lot line!  (In Dallas, Texas,) 3 years ago, to a 4 acre, open range, 3/2/5, (I have three garages!!!), with a 5500sqft. house with sub-basement.(German built in 1968!!!) My front yard is huge. My back yard is bigger. I have the grass mowed every three weeks. I do not "ever," water outside. I let my yard get to, 2 feet high, before the first mow of spring. When the weeds go to seed, it\'s time for the first mow!!! The first year there was a terrible ice storm. Trees were hanging down to the ground, tree branches snapped in two, ect. My yard men asked if I wanted all the trees pruned or cut down. I told them to not touch or cut anything. I had a pine tree that snapped in to two pieces, both pieces are still alive today!!! The trees, grass, Crape Myrtles, (35 of them!), all grew back to symmetrical trees!!! I have a water garden on my pergola, and it has cat tails, moss, Lilly pads, frogs, and koi. I do not fill it with water...the rain fills it. Unless it is going dry, then I will put some water in the pond. I also have a mixed grass prairie at the back fence. (There are no fences on the sides of my house, like I said it is open range. Total yard size: 11 acres!!! ) So, I hate yards as they are  just not real!!! I love to landscape, but, I only raise what comes up as volunteer plants. And with all that, my yard looks great!!! Yes, growing up, my dad would go and pick weeds??? Dad, this is not Texas, stadium!!!üòµ\u200düí´ I don\'t know if you call what I do as zeroscaping, but, the yard is allowed to grow however it wants. I have Rattlesnakes, Elk, Skunks, Oppusum, scorpions, eagles, porcupines, ect. So, after 60 years I finally have a beautiful yard that requires very little maintenance, no water, and weeds are okay as long as the grass is even. Brother James OSB', 'I worked in the field as a landscape designer for 12 years. I was always trying to convince clients to reduce or eliminate their lawns and replace them with a native garden. Over use of resources!  Why do I want to be so close to my neighbors which cause problems.  We want space and room for our families to have freedom to grow.  So yes, we want lawns. I think that would get a lot more people on board. 2. Not to nitpick but i strongly disagree when you lump Bose noise-cancelling headphones in with trivial things like fast fashion. I suffer from tinnitus and Bose noise-cancelling headphones have made a real difference in my life by reducing the noises that trigger my debilitating condition. There are thousands of tinnitus sufferers who have had similar experiences. I did not buy my Bose because of advertising or to keep up with the Jones‚Äôs. I bought them to alleviate a terrible medical condition and this they do really well.']

This is taught in higher education under "The History of Modern Automation and Engineering" and the industry knew this before scamming you to buy their "fake gold". Now your cars are blowing up and you haven't even hit half of the industry set life expectancy.', 'The commentary of this video is obviously by someone who lives in a highly populated area and has been duped by the climate change propaganda. ALL of the alarmist predictions that were pushed have proved to be false. If half of the predictions had been correct, most coastal areas would be under water, but the truth is that sea levels have not changed. Some areas have literally sunk but the sea has not risen.', "EV's are short distance vehicles only. Here in Australia, if you want to travel outside of a city, EV's cannot go the distance. To drive from Melbourne to Brisbane in an internal combustion engine powered vehicle takes about 21 hours and therefore is a two-day trip for most people. An EV can take at least twice as long even if you can find the places to charge the batteries. For those people driving EV's that distance, instead of one overnight stay, they can expect 3- or 4-nights' accommodation required. Good for the accommodation industry but very expensive for the traveler. Then there is the problem of cost to the environment for the production and disposal of the batteries and other components, the generation of electricity and the availability of charging stations as well as the time to re-charge.", "Three things are going to have to happen to have EVs replace ICEs: one, much improved range, two, batteries that don't have thermal runaway, three, charging stations where ever there are now gas stations and a way for apartment dwellers (there are approximately one million in Houston, Texas) to charge their cars.
People in Europe have no idea how vast this country is.  I was on a ranch of 140,000 acres (566 sq. km.) and they only had 120 volts running through it.  It is over 60 miles from one side of Houston to the other. There are towns that don't have gas stations much less charging stations.
As far as biking goes, would you bike in over 100 degree weather?  Does your company have showers to allow you to clean up after getting sweaty?
Busing is only good for those who have a lot of time, or are poor.  I once was forced to use a bus and it took me two hours to get where I needed to go whereas I could have driven it in 30 minutes.", "In 1908 cars didn't have electric starters and gas powered cars were unreliable and woman could drive a electric car with no problem,"]

['üåç  Do you own a device or piece of clothing that you think broke earlier than it should have? What are some other examples of Planned Obsolescence?
 üëç  Apparently, the algorithm appreciates it when you hit the like button... so maybe hit that like button?
üçé  I go more in-depth into degrowth and alternative economies in my consumerism video: https://youtu.be/x0ckvo2Z5BU
*** Correction: You can replace a Fairphone battery in 8 seconds, not 8 minutes!', 'Them not making DVDs and Blu rays of our fav shows anymore is kinda lame.', 'PC graphics cards including the top dogs need to be affordable for working class people.', 'Build things to last again!', 'My iPhone battery is weaker than my old one. It‚Äôs lame.', 'Watching this from my $250 Nokia phone I have had since just after 4G came out, and I have nearly all of the types of features the next to last iPhone had with a pretty great camera to boot. I own 3 iPhones though, I get them second hand and use them on Wi-Fi for different light computing tasks to make a little money, the oldest is a 5 series, and the batteries are still in great shape because I don't let them ever get below 40% (same with my Nokia). 
There are many reasons to hate the obsolescence built in by most companies, and I do. I know batteries are a solid failure point on electronics and have learned to optimize their care, but I do this with every electronic and mechanical thing I own. It takes very little time to learn how to care for things you purchase, and I think we need to also do that as a society. When you value your money, you value the things it can buy and act accordingly.
Don't get me wrong here, there is a massive need to hold the companies collective feet to the fire. I support right to repair legislation, will not buy a Tesla at any time until there is third party repair available, which is why I have never bought an iPhone or Apple product new or for more than $20. The best pair of headphones I have ever owned have ended up in the wash and dryer 2 times now and still sound as good as the day I bought them for $15, which was around 10 years ago (a tangle free non name brand, which i have definitely gotten my money's worth out of).
I constantly tell my fianc√© "Don't buy hype", and that mantra has slowly been adopted by her, as I have shown her how to spot quality items and compare options.', "unfortunate that on such an important topic, the first example first moments of this video, is unreliable and likely a bad example of misinterpretation, to put it charitably
Most likely popularised by the also unreliable Veritasium

There actually is a core principle about lightbulbs and it actually simply has more to do with physics and material science and electricity etc. than conspiracy
It has to do with the balance and ratio of longevity (voltage and burn rate) and light quality (luminosity and spectroscopy relating to emission spectrum wavelength and such as the range that's more similar to sunlight or would be more comfortable or easier on the eyes etc.)
As it's actually it's about optimal for the lightbulbs to have a specific range of relative optimal peak performance
As to increase longevity it, the materials of the filaments inside would have to burn less bright and therefore a dim poorer quality lightbulb that's bad at being a light source

You can also think of in the way that, how even to this day, with all the advancements, the lightbulbs still have the same similar if not exact hours longevity rating for the filaments and bulbs based on the same technology a/o similar materials; and that there's no company or new industry disruptors to suddenly come out with the same type of lightbulbs with similar properties suddenly lasting way way longer; because it has to also abide by the same laws of physics", 'This was an excellent program. Well produced and very informative......that was until the propaganda portion kicked in at about 09:00. Then it went head first into the "woke" end of the pool.', "A good rule of thumb is to only buy used items that were used for a decade or so. If they worked for the last 10 years and works well as they used in the past, chances are they'll still work in the future.", 'I agree that planned and perceived obsolescence is a real issue facing us. But the example of the Phoebus Cartel, and the claim that consumers buy "twice as many lightbulbs" rubs me the wrong way. In this video by @Technology Connections, he explains that the decision to lower lightbulb lifespan is an energy efficiency calculation - 1000 hrs of bright, white light vs 2500 hrs of dimmer light. Since the 1000 hr bulb is optimized, you actually get more value in terms of energy bills for lumens. 

No good will ever come from a self-branded "cartel", but sometimes engineers know what they're talking about. Down with obsolescence, and up with right to repair!

Here's the video.
https://youtu.be/zb7Bs98KmnY?si=sva7cSDWZ52xYJFG']

CO2 has been much higher in the atmosphere specially when Antarctica glaciated", 'Just why was I so good at dodging salad and other veggies as a kid? Now I have to actively train off my gag reflex to eat a piece of cucumberüò≠üò≠', 'There is no climate crisis as there is no absolute value for climate sensitivity. 

The baseline for 1.5 degrees has no rational, empirical criteria. It just sounds good to the unwary, the politically minded or just plain uncurious.', "There is no climate crisis.

- The IPCC's sixth assessment report is used to support restrictive climate change laws, but Andy May of CLINTEL identified several issues with it.
- The report made false assumptions, flawed assessments, and ignored relevant facts and research.
- The IPCC erred in comparing present data with proxy data for past climate conditions.
- Flawed assumptions were made about climate sensitivity and emissions.
- The report unjustifiably assumed that nature doesn't significantly impact climate change.
- The benefits of current climate change to human life were downplayed or ignored.
- Andy May joined a discussion on the Climate Change Roundtable to highlight these issues.
- The IPCC used RCP 8.5 as a biological model to predict other outcomes, such as synchronized crop failures.
- The report suggested that the jet stream's response to this model would lead to worldwide crop failures and dire consequences.
- The tropics were portrayed as stable, with most climate changes happening at the poles.
- Warming at the poles was associated with milder weather and thriving plant growth.
- The importance of liberalized food trade in saving lives was emphasized.
- AR 6 was criticized for including errors and omitting data on deaths.
- Mortality rates have dropped significantly in the last century.
- The number of extreme climate events is decreasing, and the cost of climate disasters is declining.
- The distortion of information aims to exert control over the population.
- Sea level rise was presented as unstoppable, but mitigation and adaptation are solutions.
- Contrary to the narrative, sea levels are not rising uniformly worldwide.
- The next ice age will likely lead to decreased sea levels.
- Some historical cities with ports are now above sea level due to changing land levels.
- The reported sea level rise of 2/1000 of a millimeter per year per year translates to a small increase in inches by 2100.
- Daily tides often exceed this rise.
- Populations at risk from sea level rise are usually located in river deltas.", 'Warning: US-centric post to follow.

This video promotes science and engineering based solutions to climate change that require governmental action. I am surprised at the naivete of this approach. In the US we have a drowning middle class, a broken healthcare system, massive legalized corruption, rising fascism, and a military industrial complex that overrides the will of the people. Activists have been fighting to fix these problems for decades. I think what happens is scientists and engineers know very much about their field, but only have the political awareness of your average person.', "04:50 'How do we get from wind producing 4% of global energy to 26% in the next 30 years?' 
We don't. Not without some effort of mass production we haven't seen since WWII. And even if we did, it would still be inadequate. Global energy demand is set to increase 50% in the next 30 years according to the IEA - and that increase in demand will be met by fossil fuels - minus a puff of wind. If we do that anyway, we will have to do it all again in 20 years - the approximate working lifetime of a wind turbine. 
Alternatively, we could cooperate to harness Magma Energy - as described by Nasa/Sandia Labs, 1982 - a source of constant high grade clean energy so vast, it can meet global energy demand many times over. 
With a not dissimilar expenditure of political will and resources, we could tap into a source of energy more than able to meet all our needs carbon free; it could also supply an abundance of surplus energy necessary to desalinate, irrigate, recycle, capture carbon etc. 
Over the next 50 years, rather than imposing politically unpopular demand side restrictions striving toward Net Zero, Magma Energy/ electrical power/ hydrogen fuel could be fed into the economy from the supply side, big industrial energy users first, reducing emissions, and supporting the economy through the transition to a prosperous and sustainable future.", 'Heres to these becoming a reality', 'i can become the plasma my self given you do what i say afterwards :D']

['Are you an REI member? How do you feel about the company?
Also, I just created an email list! You can sign up here if you want: https://www.subscribepage.com/ourchangingclimate', 'How do you have 18M people make operational decisions at a large retailer?', 'I found this very informative. I've considered starting a grass-roots campaign to get on the board of directors. Not only do I work on the floor at an REI, I have extensive backcountry and outdoor experience, as well as corporate experience working in finance and marketing. Seems like I could be an ideal candidate. But the gauntlet to get on the board seems impossible. Up through 2020 it appeared as though one could "apply" through an online form, but from what I can tell, even that has been rescinded. It appears the board has a committee that selects nominees, and that's it. 

This seems like a far, far cry from the spirit of REI, and how it was founded and run for decades. This now looks more like the board of companies like Comcast, Wells Fargo, Equifax, etc.', "REI hasn't adhered to their founding philosophy for decades. They abandoned it long ago in favor of selling overpriced status-symbols to self-important snobs. Those products aren't manufactured using more sustainable materials and greener processes. No, they are simply adorned with price tags containing higher-value numbers. Those $250 boots are made the same way and often by the same people as the $25 boots you find elsewhere. How does a shirt require a $60 selling price?

I've been a member since the 80s and I think I was only given the opportunity to vote for a board member once very early on. I've never been given the opportunity to do so since. I suspect they let members vote right after they join and then hope they forget about that part (or they simply abandoned it). Perhaps those who spend more money are given more opportunities to vote, but I can't say for certain.
I stopped shopping at REI twenty years ago because I could no longer afford to buy gear from them. 

As you said, it's not a co-op, it's a rewards card.

Anand is correct. REI like other companies make token donations for bragging rights and PR, not to effect real change toward the better because doing so would hamper their corporate growth and profit margins.  Like their products, their environmental efforts are targeted toward people who like to pretend they are helping the environment by using biodegradable coffee pods, not those willing to spend a weekend using a shovel to repair damage cause by mountain bikes and hikers.

It's weird how they were able to exercise true environmental responsibility in the past without ripping off their customers.", 'This video is the result of communists thinking other communists are not communisty enough.', 'One idea that came to mind while watching this video was library socialism.', 'All the research and attention to detail, and yet there's still a spelling error on one of the cards - "Is REI *evironmentally* ethical?"', 'REI is a laughing stock', 'I worked at REI for three years and even found myself in lower level management during that time. REI carries a lot of quality gear, but their focus is placed entirely on ‚Äúmember conversion‚Äù and growth. Their marketing platform is structured around virtue signaling, with the idea of a cooperative at the very center. They absolutely do give ‚Äúscraps‚Äù rather than substantial amounts, relative to their bottom line. They are very creative with their wording, claiming that 70% of their profits are donated; but this is very far from honest. Their employees are not expected to be knowledgeable, but are absolutely expected to push the sale of memberships as hard as possible. They simply do not emphasize training outside of member conversion. All in all, I did enjoy a lot of my time there, simply because I‚Äôm an avid outdoorsman. But seeing behind the curtain, I can absolutely say that we are all being taken for a ride by REI. Their growth matters more to them than climate change, public spaces, or actual inclusivity and access.', 'I quit shopping there and have opted for other options like buying directly from the manufactures website or locally owned stores that offer the same items.  To me this eliminates going to the store and eliminates a piece in the supply chain in the case of ordering direct or helps support local businesses.  

The dividend is not a "dividend" since it is based on what you spend and not a % of corporate profits based on your membership share.  Like the presenter said it is now a rewards program.']

['What kind of coffee do you usually buy/drink?', 'Agroforestry farming, known as Talun huma, has been practiced for centuries in Indonesia, typical South East Asian cultivation method, not just for coffee but also for other crops. When coffee was introduced to Indonesia by the colonial Dutch in 1696, following a pattern seen in other colonial regions within the coffee belt coffee became a mass-produced, globally traded commodity, largely orchestrated by European colonial powers.

European companies established themselves in coffee-producing countries, importing slaves from Africa to work on plantations in the Caribbean, Asia, and the Americas. During this period, the main beneficiaries of coffee sales were the European colonial powers and companies. However, the farmers in coffee-producing regions, like Indonesia, did not receive fair benefits and were even burdened with taxes. Eduard Douwes Dekker described this historical injustice in his famous book "Max Havelaar," also known as "Multatuli."

Despite this dark history, coffee has become the second most consumed beverage globally, which is truly remarkable. A video on this topic could hold impactful meaning for coffee consumers worldwide, encouraging awareness and appreciation for the complex history behind this beloved beverage and the impact that it would bear  from climate change and continuously increasing market demand.', 'i can reduce the amount of coffee by adding fast qualities of milk and chocolate and sugar, it gives me headache but i dont mid.', 'Just stop drinking coffee. Duh? Yes it helps you to get awake faster but it also prevents you to sleep in the evening. Thus creating the necessity to drink coffee in the morning as you get less sleep.

I stopped drinking coffee years ago and I noticed I have a way healthier sleeping rythmn am way more patient and don¬¥t sweat as much. And the taste is only good if you get used to it. Once you stop drinking it if you retry it after a  while you realize how disgusting it actually is.

From my perspective really no downsides.', 'Socialist BS and misinformation....', 'Coffee is a drug. As a muslim (closeted atheists really but this is what almost everyone here identifies me with) living in India, everytime I try to talk about the environment and how hindu and muslim festivals are effecting the environment, it may be the fireworks in Diwali or the amount of plastic thrown in barah wahfaat, I am either a hinduphobe in the former or crazy in the latter, because I am ruining the "fun". It\'s not as simple as educating them, because to educate someone you need to get them to actually listen. There\'s also the problem of getting the people to act up when they are barely supporting their families or do not get time to act up. Like, how can you even make them act up when they don\'t even have time to do so? I don\'t even know someone who is down to acting up here. Even if I act up, not more than a dozen people are really going to join even passively.', 'I am glad people are finally getting on board. It is just beyond me that basic facts and the idea that we should not destroy our entire species is political. Not dying seems pretty basic.']

['What do in your own life to minimize waste? Have you ever tried Zero Waste?', "It doesn't work. Peoplearound the globe need to elect politicians who are not narcissistic sociopaths that are serving corporations. The chain of production is the problem. Ive been living a zero waste life but I know it does nothing. Corporations need to change the way they produce and stop pushing plastic to us, but it will never happen because governments exist to serve corporations interests.", "In my opinion, achieving zero waste in today's society is very difficult. Even minimizing waste is not easy. Sometimes, we may have the misconception that not bringing garbage home is equivalent to zero waste. Unless a significant number of people reduce their consumption, production levels won't change. For instance, when you buy clothes, they come with tags and labels. Unless you buy second-hand clothes or choose fruits without individual stickers, labeled fruits will still be present. To truly make a difference in waste reduction, a shift in consumer attitudes and aesthetics within the entire community is necessary. However, it's heartening to see many people continually striving to establish new perspectives on consumption.", 'Do anything an individual can to recuce waste, but always remember the supply side is the real problem', '2:32 - was this stock footage shot by a camera they actually wanted to throw away after checking in on the elephants foot?', 'The one jar thing is silly and so is anybody pushing for individual zero waste perfection. But I think you\'re putting words in Zero Waste movement\'s mouths here as pretty much everybody in the zero waste movement would agree that the problem is structural, not individual, and that the overall solution needs to be structural too. Individual people taking an interest in zero waste and that movement snowballing is what will lead to structural change from the bottom up, like what\'s happening with the rise of plant-based food options. There\'s loads of interesting stuff in this video but there\'s no need to frame this as a "WOAH BIG PROBLEM WITH ZERO WASTE!!!" we\'re all on the same team bro. Would be better to frame it as "hey, jump on board, you don\'t need to be perfect!"', "Zigmunt Bauman: ‚ÄúEach individual seeks to construct individual solutions to society's problems, and then tries to put them into practice on the basis of his or her individual abilities. The goal is no longer a better society, but the improvement of one's individual position within that society. Instead of common rewards for collective efforts at social reform, only individual loot remains", 'The editing is craaaazy', 'The zero waste movement is basically punching down, i.e., shaming individuals for not wasting less. Like you said, sure, you can move towards zero waste with loads of effort and energy. Work a full time job, raise kids and still have time to personally harangue massive corporations to use less plastic? Not likely to happen or to be even remotely useful. _The zero waste influencers should be _*_punching up_* instead of chasing likes. If you magically have enough time to somehow only create a jar‚Äôs worth of trash in 4 years, _use your ‚Äúinfluence‚Äù to run for public office and create legislation that will *actually* solve these problems on a large scale_.', 'I think social media has kind of tainted the zero waste movement. Most of my "zero-waste" friends and I are really "low waste," and we\'ve shifted to buying as much locally as we can. And most people I know in the zero waste movement are also very vocal about lobbying companies and local elected officials, as well. The social media aspect of it all has made perfection and aesthetic the key, but in the real world, that is not the case at all. And that\'s a problem with social media and the internet, not the zero waste movement. \n\nI\'m sure someone has posted this already, but this quote says it all: "We don\'t need a few people doing zero waste perfectly, we need many people doing it imperfectly."']

['What are your thoughts on straw bans? Are you for or against them?', 'The only way to reduce Plastic Pollution is to stop producing Plastics, which by the way have massive GHG emission inherent in their production.', 'The actual solution is banning the mass production of single use plastics all together, and restructuring our society around a system of reusing packaging, and returning it to the people who use it to distribute a product. That as well as just making tools that are meant to be used indefinitely.  The biggest obstacle is convincing the ignorant masses that changing the way we package things, and putting more value on reusing tools like straws is actually necessary for the survival of the human race. 
This whole straw issue is mainly an issue because of restaurants. Restaurants dont need to exist, and in fact, they shouldnt. Nobody should be spending their days pretending to be happy serving people food and cleaning after them like a peasant. Services like that should only be provided to people who are incapable of caring for themselves, and there should be no sense of entitlement to be served by another person.
If a tiny tiny tiny minority of disabled people NEED to use plastic straws to drink, they should get them for personal use, otherwise, nobody needs them.', 'Food taste worse with paper straws and wooden cultery..', "These arguments against plastic straw bans can be made against really anything. Why can't we ____? Well, someone finds it convenient to do it the wrong way. We can't 1) prohibit hunting of polar bears to extinction because the people in Alaska need to hunt. 2) We can't transition from environmentally disastrous oil production because it would upend the livelihoods of thousands of people. 3) We can't prevent Fox News from tactfully lying to and manipulating large swaths of the public because it would be an unfair precedent for an entertainment TV show. You see where I'm going with this? You can prohibit fixing everything if you want, but you can also find alternatives. Make bamboo straws bendable. Problem solved, the planet maybe after all DOESN'T need to be destroyed and all it took was a second to think about it. Making an excuse right now why bamboo can't be bendable? I thought so. There are dozens of alternative materials including seaweed plastic-like materials, cardboard, light metal, straw and composite materials of every shape, texture, pliability and anything you could possibly make an excuse for.", "I'm a environmentalist but blanket plastic bans are something I'm opposed to. For starters plastic isn't the main detriment to our planet, it is mainly plummeting biodiversity and high CO2 emissions. I know that single use plastics play a role in both of these but it isn't a significant one when compared to oil spills,warming waters and more. Single use plastics also usually need to be replaced with another material albeit paper straws or reusable bags. In Canada there is a problem with people amassing more reusable bags than can be used, this is more wasteful than plastic bags which are often reused anyways. The narrative that stopping the use of single use plastics is key to protecting our planet is exacerbated. Lastly it is a inconvenience having your paper straw break after 20 minutes or having to buy another reusable bag because you forgot yours at home.", 'Straw bans were only ever a "feel good" solution to problems that are much harder to solve.  They were passed for the same reason we discuss them:  they have a mildly annoying impact on daily life.  That lets people who like them feel good about them.', 'Banning plastic straws to combat the human impact on natural resources is the equivalent of cleaning a neighbourhood septic tank with a toothbrush whilst everyone in the neighbourhood has violent diarrhea.', "why is the ocean a dump site for seattle and vancouver ? it's not like straw drinking takes place exlusively on the coasts.
there are rivers that dump into the ocean with trash from those two cities", 'I drink without straws. The coldest section of the cup is at the Top.üòú']

["Don't look at this video, it will uniform you. People who made it clearly haven't read what ecofeminism is about. Ecofeminism worries about any kind of life, including men, women, and actually, it is the representation itself of intersectional perspective. You should totally read before make so many people misunderstand this awesome movement.", 'https://youtu.be/ZLNequLh1y4. And here is a really good video that describes the current branches of evolving ecofeminism and its origins.', 'I agree with the comments below of CCS and Rocio Q and Nietzsche\'s Ghost.  Although there are some good points in your video - those incorrect are pretty significant - 1) That ecofeminism is sharply declining.  It is a growing movement - especially in the area of cultural, spiritual, material and radical ecofeminism which includes multiracial, Indigenous and spiritual or divine feminism such as is found in neo shamanism.  2) Ecofeminism was brought from the East to the west by a woman of colour - Physicist Vandana Shiva.  I think it\'s important to show an in depth view - not just take one point of view authoritatively from one small faction of critique.   Cultural ecofeminism developed an intersectional framework long ago.  It keeps evolving and growing with it - especially with Indigenous sustainability knowledge.  Take a look in this interview - she discusses this.   https://youtu.be/mGC1DxyISNY.  Whether she is agreed with or not by other scholars, she was/is definitely a major contributor to the field.  Feminist studies always get knocked down.  Consider Marija Gimbutas.  Twenty years after her death, Lord Renfew apologises that she was "right" all along on her Steppe migration theory.', 'Nice one.', 'Combining two cancers into one, eco-fascism and feminism. Hard pass.', 'This has to be the most cringey thing I‚Äôve ever seen.', "There's a reason why there's more dislikes than likes.", "One thing I found ironic in this video was its critique of ecofeminism being a western concept. Yet, it didn't explore non-Western ecofeminism at all. Scholars like Amanda Mokeona, Barbara Boswell, Wangari Maathai, and Tumani Mutasa Nyajeka show an African perspective of ecofeminism. Their writing shows how an ecofeminist lens can heal trauma from colonialism and apartheid. \nBy saying that ecofeminism is largely western excludes many non-western writers and theories. Although this critique is valid, the argument would have been rounded better by including other people's work (and not just work by Western women).", "Ecofeminism is more intersectional than feminism. I don't much appreciate this channel, and will likely not return. Pce", 'The overwhelming majority of vegans are women. Jus sayin']

['I just hate how lazy everyone is getting with electric scooters and bikes. I now see kids with all kinds of electric vehicles and not biking anymore. In an age when people getting fatter and unhealthier.', 'Here in Bucharest (Romania) the last scooter ride I took was for ~5 miles around 1 in the morning, as no public transport was available at that time of the day. The alternative was to take a taxi or an Uber car ride. 
The ride took me around 25 minutes, so for this context I see it as ok for the environment.', 'Dublin, Ireland is now overrun.', 'Love this channel and love the Stranger Things vibes from the background music you use also. :)', "A bunch of Lime scooters appeared overnight in my small Romanian town, where they are mostly used as toys by kids. I expect most people to get bored with them soon, as they did in Bucharest, where the only ones still using them are tech bros.
Tbh they're mostly replacing walking, and even that poorly, since European cities tend to be built differently from American ones. They can be fun, but let's say drivers were not particularly enchanted by the swarm of kids driving scooters all over town üòÇüòÇ", 'People treat the scooters like trash in my town. i always see them in ditches and broken.', "Short answer: No.
Long answer: Hell no.
Electric scooters are not environmentally friendly. A battery capacity sufficient for a 22 km range per day plus an average life time of about a month combined with being collected for recharging by truck, and not actually replacing high-carbon forms of transportation make for a terrible form of transportation. The electricity used for charging actually makes up only 5% of the emissions, so it does not matter much how the electricity is produced, what's primarily harmful are the production and transportation emissions. 
Would it be better to drive an electric scooter than drive an SUV? Yeah, sure, but you have no business driving an SUV in the first place, just go by bike if an electric scooter would have worked, that will be even better. Honestly I can't think of anything one would use a scooter for that a bicycle wouldn't be better for, so I don't think we can actually say electric scooters replace cars even in those rare instances where people claim they would have otherwise used the car, they simply displace other forms of transportation that are alltogether better for the environment.", 'No they are not', "They are definitely replacing a walk for me unfortunately - I run every other day, so when my legs are tired or it's late at night Ill take a scooter.", 'Lol My campus of filled with these. Had to delete the app though because that shot was running me $60 a week']

["What are your thoughts on legalizing weed? Do you think it will help lessen indoor cannabis's environmental impact?", 'Fun is not sustainable, quit having fun immediately', 'Comment to boost', 'The fact that your focus is on these niche little contributors which really can be solved by rearranging our economy to one not focused on profit is honestly disappointing', 'While indoor growing will always require more than outdoor, most of the high-consumption operations you see are people trying to maximize their grow as much as possible by controlling every variable. You can still get decently potent flowers without loads of expensive equipment, which a lot of people who start growing don't know.

In all cases, home growing should be encouraged as much as possible. It takes power from large companies and will force prices down, which will force quantities up. I moved from a state a year or so after they started legalizing and just moved back after 6 years. Now there's dispensaries everywhere selling half gram cartridges, pods, "disposable" vapes, jars and mylar bags containing just an eighth, all the dispensaries give you large mylar bags to put your stuff in (I get that may be required), edibles are individually packaged and even if you want multiple you just buy the display box of singles instead of for example arranged on wax paper and stacked. Even if you want a preroll, just flower wrapped in paper or leaf, they have to put a plastic tube around it and even if you buy a pack of them it generally comes in some kind of case with a plastic interior liner formed to the 5 or so little joints they put in. 

Not only are dispensaries putting tons of packaging around tiny quantities and encouraging electronics waste, but the customers themselves choose to litter all over the place. Every part of town, even commercial work areas with truck bays, warehouses, and workshops, has tons of cannabis-product waste littered on the roadsides and parking lots. There's no apparent effort to create a system for refillable or returnable vape tanks, wax jars, or flower jars.

Larger quantities being made and sold will also improve the availability of materials and knowledge and land for the growth of cannabis, which will also aid in developing the industrial uses of cannabis to create new packaging, manufacturing and building materials, biodiesel and alcohol and their blends as fuel especially in places that don't have the ethanol supply from typical agriculture for regular ethanol fuel.', "This industry is taxing on the enviorment however it isn't nearly as bad as air conditioners which use 6% of U.S electricity even with considerable regulations. Basic changes such as allowing outdoor grow-ops as well as growing plants at home can make a big difference as you stated. In addition I think mandating LED growlights which are many times more efficient would be enough to reduce the carbon footprint of this industry to low enough amounts.", 'Someone needs to tell this man about led lights...', 'You can grow indoors without any of those energy intensive devices.', 'Wow. This video is probably irrelevant now, but YouTube has restricted it. This is knowledge, people need to know.', 'üå±']
