["Absolutely! As a female climber, this is the narrative I see and experience all of the time.  That fact that you are all so triggered means there is absolute truth in all of this!! 
I'm guessing none of you also do see the control of patriarchy and toxic masculinity in society as a whole?", 'It‚Äôs clear from watching this you‚Äôve never spoken to, hung out with or experienced a mountain with fellow climbers. This film is so disrespectful to the legendary female climbers of our age like Lynn Hill, Wanda Rutkiewicz or Junko Tabei.  Women that changed the climbing world forever. And sought to summit those peaks, outside of any influence related to their gender, purely for the love of the sport and because they could. They broke barriers and changed perceptions in the process. What‚Äôs more, your myopic analysis of the story completely omits the more spiritual and emotional tenor of the film that centres on maintaining relationships in the face of loss and grief, seeking peace through achievement, and testing one‚Äôs capabilities, not in response to some negative drive, but because they strive to test themselves in the harshest and most technically demanding locations on the planet. All athletes seek to test themselves at the height of what is possible. You omit any thought of motivation coming from a place of spiritual reckoning, communing with nature and through your actions, laying testimony to the wonder of the human will and an expression of what we, as mere mortals, can be capable of. 

These great ascents are to be lauded, marvelled at, as evidence of what human beings can achieve, and I know very few people that would, upon actually talking to climbers at this level, come away with a perception that these are so called ‚Äútoxic‚Äù males. They meet death every expedition, their ego‚Äôs are well in check in the face of this constant threat, they manage loss and grief openly, emotionally, and they are more spiritually in tune with nature as a result and show great respect for the places they visit. I can‚Äôt think of three climbers who less encapsulate the overall premise of this piece and it shows that seemingly anyone can write anything these days without ever even trying to understand or even research the topic they write about, before butchering a beautiful film to make a blunt, poorly argued and utterly disingenuous thesis for the sake of regurgitating a copy and paste political talking point. 

That this writer can not see that individuals achieving great sporting milestones can be driven by anything other than conformity to toxic gender representations of masculinity in the outdoor sports community is to show complete and utter ignorance of the subject matter, and to haplessly and pointlessly negate the incredible achievements of both male and female alpinists who climb for so many more beautiful and prosaic reasons, and push themselves to their limits because they know that to do so takes them to top of our world, while bottom feeders like this writer, gripe and snipe for clicks, far below them.', '2nd dumbest video ive watched in my life. Absolute dumbest video on mountaineering ive ever watched.', 'You mean insanity', 'Still waiting for the climbers who have commented in this video to explain Renan buying a plane ticket without telling his girlfriend....', "Thank you for making this video. 
I've been reading a bunch of climbers' autobiographies lately and I climb as well and can see why some people like Alex Honnold and Tommy Caldwell push themselves to extremes for their sport. But I just watched Meru and I was pretty shocked. I felt really bad for Renan because he kept trying to tell the other two that he wasn't comfortable with what was going on only for them to either ignore him or be amused at his desire to go back down. For all of his talk about risk assessment, I think Conrad did a really poor job assessing the risk for everyone involved and not just himself. It's one thing if you want to die on the mountain you've been trying to climb your entire life but it is an entirely different thing to string someone else along who is less experienced and less willing to perish and then ignore them when they voice their fear and discomfort. 
I will definitely be checking out the resources you listed too, thanks for that! :)", 'what?! toxic?!  yikes!', 'Wow, so many triggered in this comment section. Either because they have their own definition of masculinity (which is quite common) or because they believe their masculinity is being challenged. Or they may even ridiculously believe that this video is claiming mountain climbing as being toxic masculinity.
First, the video is investigating the narratives presented in a particular movie. It‚Äôs not generically about masculinity or climbing. The people reacting to this critique clearly lack an ounce of nuance and project their insecurities onto any critique of masculinity. 
Calm down bucko, this ain‚Äôt about you. This ain‚Äôt about climbing mountains. 
You can still climb mountains and feel good about it. Do you feel better now?
But, if you see yourself reflected in the characters of these narratives, then you may want to seriously reevaluate your driving motivations.', 'What???', 'Have to say, it‚Äôs funny reading the comments section here trying to justify these guys as if they know them personally. I think the comment from Renan‚Äôs girlfriend about him not telling her he‚Äôd bought a plane ticket kinda summed up the attitude of these climbers. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôd describe this as ‚Äútoxic‚Äù masculinity, but these guys are hellishly self-centred and selfish. If a woman just left their family for months on end to risk death for the sake of climbing a mountain in the way these guys did, she would get criticised so much!']

Maybe it is even impossible for you to not think "I am that person who [...]" (where you can insert anything from "always follows the latest trends" to "always wears that worn down old clothes and cares deeply about the environment"). That is why there are brand names on the product in the first place. Because people use that brand image to define themselves.
So, the ideal brand would use recycling materials and save water and do all that stuff but sell the product without any label. I guess this wouldn't work, though. Remember? Many people are searching for some personality to buy. They could even be that guy who doesn't wear brands. It's simply capitalism, you buy anything, even your mindset.

After all, we as consumers have to behave responsibly. The circumstance that Patagonia offers repairs and have a second hand section on their website is already a step into the right direction. So let's hope the "I now buy responsibly" is the last fabricated personality people take on and that they slowly stop buying new things for good.', 'Anything to say after literally giving away the company to a non-profit organisation to fight climate change?']

["Data from NOAA (2022 Arctic Report Card) show winter (March) ice coverage has hardly changed since '79, and that the summer (September) coverage trend had stopped declining since 2007. In September 2022, sea ice reached a minimum extent of 4.87 million square kilometers in the Arctic. This is higher than the extent in 2007, which means the Arctic summer sea ice trend is zero for the past 16 years. It was almost as high as 1995. Summer 2023 is one of the coldest in several decades in the Arctic, and May 2023 was the coldest on record there. The Greenland surface mass balance (SMB) for the past 11 months is a massive but very normal 450 billion tonnes of ice accumulated. 5 out of the last 7 years have seen huge accumulations above the average (1981-2010).", "Little sperm people think it's their fault. How many active volcanoes exist on our planet.", 'The slowing the AMOC ocean circulation from warming via UV RADIATION because of thinning Ozone (not CO2) will actually cool the planet - once fresh water injected from melting glaciers in to ocean, slows it down...', 'As regards the melting of Arctic Ice, the records nearly always seem to start in 1979. Strange that, considering it was a year of record extent for Arctic Ice. Even so, data from NOAA (2022 Arctic Report Card) show winter (March) ice coverage has hardly changed since '79, and that the summer (September) coverage trend had stopped declining since 2007. How inconvenient! Didn't someone predict in 2007 Arctic ice free by 2010, or 2015, or 2013, or in 5 years? Or was it in 2008 the Arctic ice sheet would melt away. Also predicted in 2008 North Pole ice free in ... 2008 ... or in 10 years. 2009 prediction: Arctic ice free in 2014. 2012 prediction: snow will be gone by 2020. And 2013 star prediction: Methane catastrophe in 2 years because of ice free Arctic. 2018 prediction: zero chance of permanent ice in Arctic by 2022. The Arctic Ice is still there, and it's stopped shrinking. 
If you consider global sea ice cover, it was basically flat from 1981 to 2008, rose until 2010, stayed level until 2015, dropped until 2018, and then rebounded almost all the way back to the 1990-2000 average. Nobody predicted theses changes, nor can they explain them. The changes have no relationship to the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. 
The climate crisis/emergency/apocalypse is make-believe.
Multiyear ice is an unproductive habitat as far as marine organisms are concerned: first year (seasonal) ice over continental shelves is the most productive and this is where the vast majority of polar bears, seals, fish, whales, and sea birds are found. Therefore the decline of extremely thick multiyear ice (>4 years old) could be seen as an unconcerning development with regards to the wildlife in the region, especially since 2-3 year old ice that can be used as a resting/hunting platform for seals and polar bears hasn't declined in summer since 2007. In fact, biologically, the Arctic is in good shape with all its regions showing a positive trend in primary productivity over an extended period (2003-2022). This has resulted in more food for seals, walruses, bowhead whales and polar bears, which are  hence maintaining or expanding their populations. 
There's no "death spiral" in the region as some people reported. In fact, there is, as I say, no evidence of any crisis/emergency. That is silly nonsense designed to scare people.', 'So as predicted by climate science, the Arctic is warming four times faster than the global average due to polar amplification. Also temperature measurements of the Arctic back then are irrelevant in the big picture, as what contributed to that inter-decadal nature of the 1930s was a particular pattern of sea level pressure fields and temperature anomalies with warm temps in both West Greenland and Europe. How are we getting global temperature data points from the 1880's? You're saying this is showing anomalies from an average? It's rather convenient that the average is taken from  the coldest period ever recorded in recent times. We did not have a global network of temperature data points to know what was average back in the 1880's. (We only had about 226 stations - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Historical_Climatology_Network ) The only places that have long term daily temperature records is the United States, Europe and parts of Japan ( https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:GHCN_Temperature_Stations.png ), and many of those data points show a substantial increase in temperature during the 1930's (Dust Bowl era) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_North_American_heat_wave  -  Interesting that in this video the regions of "the poles" actually go to 40 degrees latitude (which include places like Naples Italy - hardly arctic). That same data is showing substantial cooling during the 60's and into the early 70's - https://www.sciencenews.org/sn-magazine/march-1-1975 - (Again this is the time frame that they are getting their "average" from) It is not possible to accurately plot global temperature variations that far back (1880's) when there wasn't a global network of weather stations on earth back then. We only started recording temperatures at the south pole in the late 50's. Which by the way "a South Pole weather station recorded six months of record cold temperatures in 2021", which will be dismissed as "simply weather", but any 3 day span with record heat anywhere on the planet is more proof of disastrous climate change.

I'm not saying we can't improve our planet, but we will kill 100's of millions of people by exposure and starvation if we simply flip the switch to a non-fossil fuel power source tomorrow. Look at what's happening in Germany right now with the potential loss of gas and oil supplies from Russia. There is real concern about people suffering - and again the poor will suffer the most. We are not yet ready to make that change globally. The poorest of countries and poorest of people will suffer the greatest if we make that switch too soon. And there is nothing green about mining the cobalt, nickel, and lithium needed for the EV revolution. We will be emitting as much if not more greenhouse gases switching to renewables and have done nothing to lower global temperatures.

If we really are this certain of a planetary disaster, then why aren't we showing it by our actions? Why are coastal properties still so desirable? why are we still upgrading our phones every 2 years?  Why are we buying cars? (and I mean any car - EV or ICE - they both contribute substantially to our carbon footprint). Perhaps we see that the earth isn't really falling apart as "they" say. We've been told the "end is near" since I was in junior high in the early 1980's and that we will see a 10-30 foot sea level rise by the year 1990 . . . 2000 . . . 2010 . . . 2020 . . . but the reality is that we aren't seeing that kind of increase, not by a long shot.  Miami isn't covered by 20 feet of ocean, it's still just as desirable a place to live as it was 40 years ago.

Let's not allow manipulated graphs and sketchy data points to lead us down an accelerated path that will create more damage and more suffering than if we allow the natural order of change to take place and make sure the poor do not suffer because of fear of not doing enough - fast enough, when what we are seeing in the real world doesn't match what the alarmist are showing with their graphs.', 'So we see earth progress to red indicating hotness, what color comes after red? Will it just burst into flames in a couple of years?']

['Ice ages are indeed controlled by orbital cycles.
But the true terrestrial feedback mechanism is ice sheet albedo (and dust), not CO2.
It is the sudden dust-peaks that lower ice-sheet albedo, and allow melting.
And the sudden dust peaks are caused by LOW CO2, not high CO2.
See my science paper on this.
Modulation of Ice Ages by Dust and Albedo
   https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987116300305

Will we get a new ice age? The next Great Winter (Milankovitch Minima) is weak, so that is uncertain.
What we DO know is that CO2 has NO effect on ice ages.  When CO2 levels are high, the world cools i to an ice age.  When CO2 levels are low, the world warms into an interglacial.  The climate would not do that, if CO2 was the primary feedback system.  In truth, the primary feedback is ice albedo and dust.

So the primary thing that will prevent a new ice age is Chinese industrial dust on the northern ice sheets.  

And why is anyone afraid of high CO2 and warmth?  Dinosaurs thrived in that environment.  CO2 is plant food, and the most important gas in the atmosphere.  It is the increased plant growth, due to high CO2, that underpinned the large size of dinosaurs.  Conversely, it was the very low CO2 during the ice age maximum that created CO2 deserts and nearly kiIIed off all life on Earth.  

Ralph.', 'I went through the paper published in Feb 2018 in The Journal of Geology about extraordinary biomass burning around 10,800 BCE. I found it fascinating.
